Update: HR 4779 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Next up is HR 4779, a bill to extend US SAFEWEB Act of 2006, which was introduced by @cathymcmorris, @RepRobinKelly & @RepLarryBucshon. This bill reauthorizes the U.S. SAFE WEB Act through FY 2027 and requires that the @FTC report to Congress how it uses the act. pic.twitter.com/hc1TN8bCfZ
Update: HR 3851 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.
Next is HR 3851, the Brand USA Extension Act, introduced by @PeterWelch and @RepGusBilirakis. This bipartisan bill will #RenewBrandUSA through 2027. pic.twitter.com/OEP6HdXfz0
Update: H. Res. 575 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Next up is H. Res. 575, expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that all stakeholders in the deployment of 5G should carefully consider and adhere to the recommendations adopted at The Prague Proposals, introduced by @RepBillFlores and @RepDarrenSoto. pic.twitter.com/NJ3GZPvPwc
Update: HR 4500 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

HR 4500, the Promoting United States Wireless Leadership Act, was introduced by @RepWalberg and @RepDebDingel. It directs @NTIAgov to encourage and offer technical assistance to stakeholders to develop standards for 5G networks and future generations of communications networks. pic.twitter.com/GtZaaBvdEm
Update: HR 2881 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

HR 2881, the Secure 5G and Beyond Act, introduced by @RepSpanberger, @RepStefanik, @RepSlotkin, @RepRooney, @RepOHalleran & @SusanWBrooks, directs @POTUS to develop the Secure Next Generation Mobile Communications Strategy. pic.twitter.com/yR0aKdAk7m
Update: HR 4461 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

HR 4461, the Network Security Information Sharing Act, introduced by @RepKinzinger and Subcommittee Chair @USRepMikeDoyle, establishes a program for federal agencies to share supply chain security risks with communications & telecom providers. pic.twitter.com/5cLaM1KERZ
Update: HR 4998 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.
The bill also establishes a reimbursement program to assist communications providers with the costs of removing and replacing prohibited equipment and services from their networks.

HR 4998, the Secure and Trusted Communications Networks Act. Introduced by Chair @FrankPallone, RM @repgregwalden, @DorisMatsui& @RepGuthrie. It requires @FCC to develop and maintain a list of communications equipment and services that pose a risk to security and prohibit usage. pic.twitter.com/gjgnwyipIK
Update: HR 5000 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

HR 5000, the SHARE Act, introduced by Subcommittee Chair @USRepMikeDoyle and RM @boblatta, requires the @NTIAgov and @FCC to establish a spectrum sharing prototyping program and test bed to explore new ways for Federal entities to share spectrum. pic.twitter.com/7GhzlwHSo8
Update: HR 4227 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Now up for debate is HR 4227, the MAPS Act. Introduced by @RepMcEachin and @USRepLong, this bipartisan bill specifies that it is unlawful for a person to willfully, knowingly or recklessly submit inaccurate broadband service data. pic.twitter.com/Ofb87ioNiU
Update: HR 4229 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

HR 4229, the Broadband DATA Act, was introduced by @daveloebsack and @boblatta. It requires the @FCC to issue new guidelines to require the collection and dissemination of granular broadband availability data and to establish a process to verify its accuracy. pic.twitter.com/fzZv6hVVpq
Update: HR 4996 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

HR 4996, the MOMS Act, introduced by @RepRobinKelly, @michaelcburgess, @RepUnderwood, @cathymcmorris, @RepPressley & @RepBuddyCarter, extends continuous Medicaid or CHIP eligibility for one year postpartum. pic.twitter.com/8wuTmm8rgs
Update: HR 535 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a vote of 31-19.

There are thousands of stories just like Emily Marpe‚Äôs happening all around our country. PFAS and PFOA are contaminating our drinking water and putting human health at risk. That is why this Committee is advancing comprehensive legislation to combat this environmental problem. pic.twitter.com/AMeae3O0UM
The PFAS Action Act incorporates text from 11 additional bills addressing PFAS. pic.twitter.com/JZdOyc5V6c

HR 535, the bipartisan PFAS Action Act, introduced by @RepDebDingell and @RepFredUpton, would require the @EPA Administrator to designate all per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances as hazardous under the Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA). pic.twitter.com/FYLFSMnCnH
Update: HR 2699 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Now up is HR 2699, the Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act, introduced by @RepMcNerney and @RepShimkus. The bipartisan bill amends the Nuclear Waste Policy Act to update the Department of Energy‚Äôs ability to manage nuclear waste. pic.twitter.com/1jZnXGx9eZ
Update: HR 5035 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Additionally, it requires tv, internet, and phone providers to include all charges in the prices they advertise and bill for services, allows greater transparency in electronic bills and provides remedies to consumers for certain increases in charges.

GOOD NEWS, last night E&C passed the Reversing the Youth Tobacco Epidemic Act. The bill now heads to the House floor.  

The legislation:
üö≠Prohibits flavors
üö≠Raises min purchasing age to 21
üö≠Protects kids from predatory marketing https://www.politico.com/news/2019/11/19/house-panel-vaping-ban-trump-071820¬†‚Ä¶
The Committee markup has recessed for the day and will resume tomorrow, 30 minutes after the conclusion of the Environment & Climate Change Subcommittee hearing. pic.twitter.com/kixlXeBsZn
Update: HR 2339 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a vote of 28-24.

Nearly all tobacco use begins during youth and young adulthood. Congress must pass the Reversing the Youth Tobacco Epidemic Act, which provides FDA with the tools and resources needed to respond to this emerging public health crisis. pic.twitter.com/2oJZJ65nL5

Studies show that youth use of mint and menthol products increased after JUUL restricted the availability of other flavors, like mango. It‚Äôs time for a comprehensive ban on flavored tobacco products. pic.twitter.com/FnFdlPiEVe
This bill would recognize cigarettes, e-cigarettes and other tobacco products equally under law and protects kids from tobacco product marketing. pic.twitter.com/1G4P6owgjb

Now up is HR 2339, the Reversing the Youth Tobacco Epidemic Act, introduced by Chairman @RepFrankPallone and @RepShalala. The legislation prohibits flavored tobacco products and increases the minimum age for purchasing tobacco products to 21. pic.twitter.com/rxZuJG4fNX
Update: HR 4995 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

These programs are intended to strengthen maternal health quality and access to care in rural areas, address racial and ethnic disparities in maternal health outcomes and provide grants to implement best practices in maternal health care and strengthen training programs.

Update: HR 1603 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a vote of 47-1.

Tens of thousands of deaths every year ‚Äì and the U.S. continues to use and import asbestos. No more. These deaths are preventable. It‚Äôs time to say enough and pass the #BanAsbestosNow Act. pic.twitter.com/pXj0ucTVvk

Anything less than a complete ban on asbestos is an abdication of our responsibility to protect the health & safety of the American people.

WATCH @Linda_ADAO talk about the impact asbestos has on families and why we need to #BanAsbestosNow. pic.twitter.com/FVz4PyTu6N

Coming up is HR 1603, the Alan Reinstein #BanAsbestosNow Act, which was introduced by @RepBonamici, @RepSlotkin & Chairman @Frankpallone. It would completely ban the production, use and importation of asbestos, which kills 40,000 Americans each year. pic.twitter.com/OXmezyUgTP

The hazardous liquid and natural gas industry is estimated to be responsible for 1/3 of US methane emissions.

The SAFER Pipelines Act works to curb this by preserving the 2016 @EPA final rule limiting methane emissions.
